items.title: amsynth not keeping up with midi events

milestone.description:
Release notes:

* Fixed bug causing delay on ALSA MIDI input
* Allow microtonal in plugins
* MIDI CCs are now emitted automatically when parameters are changed or presets loaded
* Added French and German translations
* Worked around non-responsive UI when used as VST plugin in a JUCE based host such as Tracktion
* Fixed icon installation locations and install new scalable icon

https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/compare/release-1.6.4...master

items.body:
I've been fooling with a midi controller and amsynth, and finding that amsynth often gets behind.  E.g., if I play a repeated triad at about 180bpm while simultaneously moving a fader, the rhythm goes ragged and amsynth will still continue trying to play notes for several seconds after I've stopped.  I can also reproduce the problem without touching any other controls if I just play a long fast glissando.

The one other soft synth I tried (bristol's b3 emulation) didn't see this problem, so I'm assuming it's an amsynth issue.

I'm on Fedora 24 with amsynth-1.6.4.1.fc24.  I'm inexperienced with linux music, but experienced with linux development, and happy to build newer versions from git, etc., if that would help debug.  I'm running amsynth on a new laptop (Lenovo T460s w/ Core i7-6600U CPU @ 2.60GHz).  Setup is all Fedora defaults, using qjackctl to set up jack, except that I had to bump some ulimits so that jack and amsynth could succesfully memlock and get realtime priority.

items.title: VST GUI does not work under JUCE-based hosts

milestone.description:
Release notes:

* Fixed bug causing delay on ALSA MIDI input
* Allow microtonal in plugins
* MIDI CCs are now emitted automatically when parameters are changed or presets loaded
* Added French and German translations
* Worked around non-responsive UI when used as VST plugin in a JUCE based host such as Tracktion
* Fixed icon installation locations and install new scalable icon

https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/compare/release-1.6.4...master

items.body:
Hosts that exhibit this problem include:
- [JUCE/examples/audio plugin host](https://github.com/julianstorer/JUCE/tree/master/examples/audio%20plugin%20host) 
- [Tracktion](https://www.tracktion.com/products/t5-daw)

The amsynth GUI displays fine but mouse clicks are not detected.

This is because GTK button press events are not being generated - using `gdk_event_handler_set` to inspect all events reveals that GDK is not emitting `GDK_BUTTON_PRESS` events.

An initial round of debugging points to this being an issue with the way JUCE forwards XEvents to the plugin's child window. JUCE uses `XSendEvent` (see [juce_VSTPluginFormat.cpp](https://github.com/julianstorer/JUCE/blob/95c66f5659141b943d8d097902da571812924ab7/modules/juce_audio_processors/format_types/juce_VSTPluginFormat.cpp#L2343)) but GDK seems to ignore mouse clicks that have the `send_event` flag set - whether this is intentional or not I do not yet know.

A crude workaround is to not reparent amsynth's GUI window inside the JUCE-owned parent. Event handling then works fine, but this leads to two top-level windows being seen.

Installing an `_XEventProc` may offer a solution, but so far attempts to get this working on a 64-bit machine have caused crashes. It's not clear whether this mechanism is widely used and therefore reliably implemented in hosts.

Further investigation required...
- [x] _XEventProc 64-bit support
- [x] mouse event handling
- [x] popup menus
- [ ] parameter value tooltips

items.title: Automatically send settings to midi_out

milestone.description:
Release notes:

* Fixed bug causing delay on ALSA MIDI input
* Allow microtonal in plugins
* MIDI CCs are now emitted automatically when parameters are changed or presets loaded
* Added French and German translations
* Worked around non-responsive UI when used as VST plugin in a JUCE based host such as Tracktion
* Fixed icon installation locations and install new scalable icon

https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/compare/release-1.6.4...master

items.body:
Dear Nick,

I've been using amsynth for a while and first thank you for this very good software!
I saw recently that, at some point, amsynth was automatically sending its parameters through the midi_out port, but it does not seem to be the case on my version which I compiled from git.

Is this feature scheduled again? I found it very useful when changing from patterns to patterns without having a "jump" in the parameter when touching a knob.

I can help as far as I know of C++ if you want!

Cheers,

Tom

items.title: Build Error with libsigc++ 2.62
items.body:
I'm trying to build on slackware64 14.2 and get this error:

/usr/include/gtkmm-2.4/gtkmm/treeview.h:2289:5:   required from here
/usr/include/sigc++-2.0/sigc++/functors/slot.h:177:72: error: ‘operator()’ not defined
       return (typed_rep->functor_).SIGC_WORKAROUND_OPERATOR_PARENTHESES<type_trait_take_t<T_arg1>,

Any ideas how to fix it?

items.title: Enable microtonal in presets
items.body:
Hi,

I am always with my idea of micro-tuning. I work with amsynth in a raspberry with a master keyboard, and, with that setup, I just can't change my tuning during a song. I have to shutdown all my things, change a file on a SD and reload everything. So, I was thinking about how change that...
One solution will be to work with SysEx midi and doing some midi-vodoo to implement this idea through midi signal: When a signal is received, it change the scale. But this is not very useful, you will have to specify a list of scale, and change a lot the code.

The other solution, much better I think was to implement a new parameter in the presets, a scale, like a path to a different tuning file (or, much better I think, include this file in the preset). Now you can change the scale trough midi (by changing the preset), and adapt your preset according to the scale.
Even better, adding a note reference (different than a A 440), because doing a 16-tone per octave only in 440 is not very funny...

It will need some adjustment, but what do you think about that ?

items.title: Allow microtonal in plugins
items.body:
Hi

Just added few lines to allow the use of microtonal tunings in plugins (at least with dssi) through the conf file. It builds and works fine with rosegarden in Fedora 24.

I don't know if it is the better way to make it work, but it works :)

items.title: MIDI Learn
items.body: There is any way to save as default configuration the linked param (sustain, volume...) with MIDI CC? Or to do the "lean midi" option via terminal? My idea is when synth starts, all the knobs of my midi controller where linked without have to do it again manually. Thanks!

items.title: Package 1.6.4 for Ubuntu and Debian
items.body:
Please, (help) package 1.6.4 for Ubuntu and Debian. See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/amsynth/+bug/1537727

I also noted that https://amsynth.github.io/ still lists 1.6.3 as latest release, so you might want to update that too.

items.title: Incorrect Icon Location

milestone.description:
Release notes:

* Fixed bug causing delay on ALSA MIDI input
* Allow microtonal in plugins
* MIDI CCs are now emitted automatically when parameters are changed or presets loaded
* Added French and German translations
* Worked around non-responsive UI when used as VST plugin in a JUCE based host such as Tracktion
* Fixed icon installation locations and install new scalable icon

https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/compare/release-1.6.4...master

items.body: The installer puts the icon in `@prefix@/share/pixmaps/amsynth.png` which breaks freedesktop guidelines. It should actually go in `/usr/share/icons/hicolor/` and then the icon line of the [.desktop file](https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/blob/master/data/amsynth.desktop.in#L8) should just read `Icon=amsynth`. This allows theme developers to properly theme the icon and prevents breakage in style consistency.

items.title: Volume gets reset each time I change presets
items.body: Each time I change presets in amsynth, I'm forced to move my MIDI keyboard's volume lever up and then back down again in order to get amsynth to recognize my set volume level.  It would be really great if the volume level could stay constant.

items.title: Modify default tuning at startup
items.body:
Hi,

I run amsynth on rapsberry pi, in headless mode, and I want to load a tuning file at startup. I think is a good idea to add this in a command line option, and, better, to allow the user to change the tuning with midi signal.

For now, I have modified a little bit amsynth sources to load a tuning file at startup from .Amsynthrc, with a line called tuning_file (you can see the sources here: https://github.com/nobrakal/amsynth). It's not really beautiful since I'm not a c programmer, but it's work.

items.title: saved parameter of patch aren't reflected in the UI of amsynth VST on reload
items.body:
Hi Nick,

I said on linuxmusicians(tripomatic) that the vst was running fine in Bitwig, but i noticed now that there are problems. The patch is being saved fine. If I a reopen bitwig/project/UI the parameters don't show up in the UI however the patch sounds like it's saved. 

Look like the UI isn't picking up the save parameters? This is in Bitwig 1.3 and 1.2 also. 

little screencast for the issue: 
http://users.telenet.be/tripomatic/amsynth_vst_bitwig.mp4

Greetings,
Stijn

items.title: Another oscillator?
items.body: Three detunable oscillators is a nice minimum to get a good supersaw going on. AM is a really nice synth, but if feels a little bit limited by only having 2 oscillators.

items.title: Amsynth with automation lets Ardour4 crash
items.body:
I have a project stub with only Amsynth and an automation in it, where Ardour crashes, when it plays to the end of an automation near a note.

The error line Ardour gives out before it crashes is:

"
ardour-4.2.546: src/Synthesizer.cpp:188: void Synthesizer::process(unsigned int, std::vector<amsynth_midi_event_t>&, float_, float_, unsigned int): Zusicherung »frames_until_next_event < frames_left_in_buffer« nicht erfüllt.
"

But this only happens, if the automation is ending near the last note, I think. If it ends somewhere else or if I play a loop, it wont crash there, but if I change automation while playing, it crashes again.

I use a realtime kernel with Debian Jessie and the Mate-Desktop and I use KXStudio, so the software is up to date.

I have uploaded the little project stub on wikisend.com, so you may inspect the behavior yourself:

http://wikisend.com/download/827318/amsynthBreaksArdour.tar.xz

The link is only valid for 7 days, it says. Please let me know, if you could not download it till then, so I may upload it again there or somewhere else. GitHub wont take the file.

By the way, I think Amsynth is awesome. In combination with automation you can create all sorts of drum sounds or funny or eerie synth sounds. Its just perfect.

Richard

items.title: Tuning Issues.
items.body:
Hi,

I downloaded and compiled amsynth 1.6.0 for use as a LV2 plugin in Muse. However, the synth plays one to two semitones over the assigned midi key ( ie C4 plays as C#4, A4 plays as A#4 etc) as it did in 1.5.1.

The standalone versions of Amsynth always plays in tune just fine - it seems to be just the LV2 plugin is out of tune.

Regards,
Chris.

items.title: LFO "minimum level" feature
items.body: I control the LFO with a MIDI controller which is part of my piano. Unfortunately, if I set the LFO level via the GUI and then move the MIDI controller, the level will return to 0 when I don't hold the controller anymore. It would be really handy if setting the LFO level via the GUI would also set a "minimum level" below which the LFO level will never go. So even when the controller is sending a MIDI signal to set it to 0, it wouldn't go back.

Hi,

I currently package amsynth for Fedora, and the package-review tool complains about the FSF address (you use the old one): "E: incorrect-fsf-address /usr/share/licenses/amsynth/COPYING ".

Here is the corrected address, based on http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.txt

Thank you in advance

items.title: Replace the linear ADSR with an exponential ADSR
items.body:
The exponential ADSR is based on a single-pole low pass filter.

Note, this patch changes the sound of every preset because of the difference in ADSR type.
Exponential ADSR change smoothly, especially for the AMP ENV, whereas the linear ADSR causes AMP ENV to change abruptly (notable on presets with short release that are meant for keys; e.g. Pianola from BrianBanks1).
This behaviour is said to be similar to classic analog synths.

Unfortunately since both AMP ENV and FILTER ENV uses the same ADSR class, the FILTER ENV is also changed.
For me personally, exponential ADSR is always preferable for AMP ENV, while for FILTER ENV linear ADSR is different, but not less preferable.

Would it be better to have both? if so then there should be a way of choosing between them.
I could think of two ways of switching,
- a switch between the old linear or newer exp,
- or a knob where linear behaviour is simulated with having large overshoot and scaling.

Thoughts?
